results.title: Last call at Maud's
results.creator_credit: Waterbearer Films, Karen Kiss and Paris Poirer
results.brief_description: Nostalgic look at an institution of lesbian culture in San Francisco—the legendary bar Maud’s. Closing in 1989 after more than 30 years of business, the history of Maud’s parallels the the evolution of the lesbian community and the gay rights movement in the United States. Through the reminisces and coming out stories of some of the bar’s long standing patrons, and the use of personal and public archival footage, a largely repressed history of lesbian social life emerges, beginning with the secret world of lesbian bars in the 1940s, through to the frightening vice raids of the 1950s, the colorful gay counter culture of the 1960s and the golden era of gay and lesbian life in San Franscisco in the 1970s and ending with the a reflection on the profound shifts in queer culture that took place in the 1980s. A witty and informative look at the emergence of a distinctly lesbian cultural life with its own unique codes through the eyes of the lesbian women who contributed to its shape.

results.title: Lassie come home
results.brief_description: You’ll find overwhelming drama and excitement in the dangerous journey undertaken by Lassie from Scotland to her young master’s home in Yorkshire. Roddy McDowell plays Joe, an endearing character, with Donald Crisp and Elsa Lancaster as his parents. Watch out for Elizabeth Taylor in her second movie appearance. Rated: G

results.title: Lasers: an introduction
results.brief_description: Principles of laser operation are illustrated, including concepts of coherent and incoherent light, continuous and discrete spectra, stimulation of atoms, and resonance. Gaseous and crystalline lasers are shown to be valuable tools of holography, communications, medicine and industry.

results.title: Laser: the light of the future
results.creator_credit: Prism Productions, National Educational Television and Mauri Goldberg
results.brief_description: Describes the contribution of Dr Arthur Schawlow, head of the Department of Physics at Stanford University to the development of the ruby laser. An electronic organ coupled to an oscilloscope helps show why getting light “in step” is so difficult. A working model of atoms demonstrates how ordinary light is produced and how laser light is generated and controlled.

results.title: Laser safety
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Barry Pollack
results.brief_description: Introduces the laser, illustrating the properties which make it useful, but explaining that it can be harmful to biological tissue. Demonstrates safety measures to prevent injury to eyes and skin.

results.title: Laser
results.brief_description: Light Amplification of Stimulated Emission of Radiation: this is the laser, the new wonder tool that can bore holes in steel, perform delicate eye operations and carry thousands of simultaneous telephone conversations and television channels. Communications with men on the moon may well be by means of a laser beam, and there is speculation about their use as “death rays” to bring down missiles in flight.

results.title: Las Vegas
results.creator_credit: United Airlines, Film and Television Communications and Vern Barry
results.brief_description: Las Vegas, Nevada, as seen through the eyes of a “go-go” girl. During the daytime various kinds of sports are seen, whilst at night the entertainment city comes to life with activities in casinos, at stage shows and restaurants. No dialogue - music only.

results.title: Larsen and Lewers
results.creator_credit: Crafts Council of Australia and Dinah Van Dugteren
results.brief_description: Presents the lives and works of jewellery making couple, Helge Larsen and Darani Lewers. Shows the way they work and their ideas on jewellery and craft.

results.title: Larger than life: garden jungle
results.creator_credit: Mantis Wildlife Films, Densey Clyne and Jim Frazier
results.brief_description: Reveals the teeming wildlife to be found in a suburban garden, and traces the activities of common invertebrate animals through an Australian summer.

results.title: Lara Croft: tomb raider (Special collector's edition) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Mutual Film Company, Lawrence Gordon, Lloyd Levin, Colin Wilson and Simon West
results.brief_description: From the video game “Tomb raider” comes the first live action film, featuring heroine (and internet icon) Lara Croft. Lady Croft is an aristocrat who enjoys breaking the rules and shocking her peers by subverting her femininity. She is astute, athletic, a talented sharpshooter, an authority on archaeology and a dextrous woman who misses her daddy. Lara discovers an ancient clock that (when combined with its missing pieces) is able to control time. It is up to Lara to destroy the clock and prevent its power from falling to the Illuminati - a secret society that aims to harness this mystic force perpetuated by a rare planetary alignment that occurs every 5000 years. The film is a modern mix of digital effects and live action sequences filmed at various exotic locations including Cambodia and Iceland. Jolie certainly looks the part with her large bosom and lithe physique, but her performance is decidedly clunky and heavy handed. Paying a huge debt to Indiana Jones, “Lara Croft” is steeped in a faux mysticism (intriguing given that most characters are either killing, maiming or at the very least destroying ancient tombs) but despite its flaws still manages to achieve a certain level of escapist fun.
